The correct sequence is B: 1 -> 3 -> 2 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6.
First, the man introduces Willow Creek Trail in Springwater and notes that the forest is mostly pine. This sets the scene for the hike and establishes the topic of the conversation.
Next, a close-up appears labeled "Eastern Hemlock," and the man explains hemlock traits. This provides additional context about the types of trees found in the forest.
Afterward, a hand displays pine needles and a small cone as he discusses needles in groups of 2 vs 5. This reinforces the discussion on the characteristics of pine trees.
An upward shot of an oak with a few dry leaves appears as he says oaks keep their dry leaves. This provides visual interest and further emphasizes the diversity of tree species in the forest.
Finally, he holds a sprig labeled "Black Spruce" and describes its round, pointed needles and mentions vitamin C tea. This concludes the discussion on pine trees and moves on to another type of tree.
The white birch is highlighted ("Paper/White Birch") as he describes its oily, kerosene-like bark and creek sounds begin. This brings the conversation full circle by returning to the natural setting of the trail and tying together all

The correct order is A: 1 -> 3 -> 2 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6.
First, he examines White Oak bark, comparing its long, fissured plates to an elephant trunk (option A). Then, he holds a Black Spruce sprig and explains its round, non-flat needles (option B). Next, he highlights a single Paper/White Birch and says its oily bark burns like kerosene, as water sounds begin (option C). After that, he mentions it's the first week of February, about a 3 km hike, and warm temps are melting snow (option D). We see his feet with ice cleats as he says they help him not slip (option E). Finally, he concludes by saying heâ€™s glad he finished before dark, thanking viewers, and asking them to subscribe (option F).
